Distribution: Distribution Process
   
  What is Distribution?  
         
 

Distribution is defined in the APICS Dictionary as:

…activities associated with the movement of material, usually finished goods or service parts, from the manufacturer to the customer. These activities encompass the functions of transportation, warehousing, inventory control, material handling, order administration, site and location analysis, industrial packaging, data processing, and the communications network necessary for effective management. It includes all activities related to physical distribution, as well as the return of goods to the manufacturer.

Distribution as defined by Joint Pub 1-02 is "The operational process of synchronizing all elements of the logistics system to deliver the "right things" to the "right place" at the "right time" to support the geographic combatant commander."

  

Distribution management is the function of synchronizing and coordinating a complex set of networks (physical, communications, and financial) and functional components (supply, transportation, maintenance, and logistics management) to achieve responsive, customized solutions to warfighter requirements. The Air Force view is simply all the activities required to identify and transfer resources from one location to another. Functionally, it is the fusion of supply and transportation.

As the Department of Defense seeks to reengineer its distribution process, it is learning what private industry began learning about 20 years ago: it is cheaper to move things than to make, buy, and store things. Expressed another way, it is less expensive in the long run, and in terms of cost to the total system, to pay a higher price for faster, better, more reliable ( “premium”) transportation than to carry inventory.
